  "translated_text": "President Roh Moo-hyun and U.S. President George Bush, visiting Hanoi, Vietnam to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, announced on the 18th their intention to provide economic assistance and security guarantees as 'corresponding measures' if North Korea abandons its nuclear program. The two leaders held a summit meeting that day and discussed such measures, stating that "North Korea's possession of nuclear weapons is absolutely unacceptable," according to Song Min-soon, Director of National Security Policy at the Blue House. After the meeting, President Bush said at a press briefing, "I want North Korean leaders to know that if North Korea abandons its nuclear weapons and nuclear ambitions, we will enter into consultations about providing security guarantees for North Korea and economic incentives." White House spokesperson Tony Snow provided additional clarification, explaining that regarding President Bush's statement that "security for North Korea and corresponding measures would be provided if North Korea abandons its nuclear program," "a formal declaration ending the Korean War could be included." He explained that the corresponding measures the U.S. would take "include economic cooperation and strengthening ties in areas such as culture and education." Spokesperson Snow said, "President Bush views North Korea's announcement of returning to talks as a moment of opportunity," and "the two leaders discussed the importance of cooperating within the six-party talks framework to make clear that North Korea must abandon its nuclear program."

Resumption of Mortgage Loans: Major commercial banks including Kookmin and Shinhan, which had suspended new mortgage loans on the 17th, decided to resume normal mortgage lending operations starting this week. The banks, which had completely suspended new loans following de facto total lending volume control measures by financial supervisory authorities, changed their stance and decided to provide mortgage loans to actual homebuyers. Kookmin and Shinhan banks, which had completely suspended new loans due to the Financial Supervisory Service's 'window guidance,' urgently sent official notices to their branches instructing them to provide loans to actual homebuyers as before. A Kookmin Bank official said on the 19th, "We withdrew the plan to carry over new mortgage loans to December," and "We plan to make 100% loans available especially to loan applicants who are in urgent financial situations after signing real estate purchase contracts." Kim Jung-hoe, Deputy Governor of the Financial Supervisory Service, said, "Customer complaints arose due to the suspension of new loans, so we requested that commercial bank working-level staff not suspend new loans to actual homebuyers," and "The FSS never requested total volume control of collateral loans from commercial banks in the first place." Meanwhile, starting on the 20th, the Debt-to-Income ratio (DTI), which limits mortgage loan amounts based on income, will be applied not only to apartments over 600 million won [approximately $450,000 USD] in speculative areas but also to speculative overheating districts in the Seoul metropolitan area.

'Seoul Reconstruction' Prices Drop: The surge in Seoul reconstruction apartment prices appears to have dropped for the first time since Chuseok [Korean autumn harvest festival]. While the price decline is not large, this is the first time Seoul apartment prices have fallen since Chuseok, leading to analysis that this could be the beginning of a full-scale price drop. According to the real estate industry on the 19th, the 16-pyeong [approximately 530 square feet] units at Godeok-dong Jugong Complex 3, which had risen by 50-70 million won [approximately $38,000-53,000 USD] in the past month, were asking 610-620 million won [approximately $460,000-470,000 USD] before the November 15th measures but are now 600-605 million won [approximately $450,000-455,000 USD]. An official at a licensed real estate agency in Seoul's Godeok-dong said, "Homeowners' anxiety about price drops is growing, and distressed sales are appearing one by one." Seoul's Gangdong District Dunchon Complex has also entered a wait-and-see phase, with properties gradually increasing and returning to a weak sideways trend. For 16-pyeong units at Dunchon Jugong Complex 1, asking prices dropped from 670-680 million won [approximately $505,000-515,000 USD] to 650-660 million won [approximately $490,000-500,000 USD]. Seoul's Songpa District Jugong Complex 5 is also seeing an increasing number of distressed sales. 34-pyeong [approximately 1,120 square feet] units are showing 1.3-1.32 billion won [approximately $980,000-995,000 USD], and 36-pyeong [approximately 1,190 square feet] units are in the 1.63-1.65 billion won [approximately $1.23-1.24 million USD] range. This represents a drop of about 10-20 million won [approximately $7,500-15,000 USD] from peak prices in the past month. An official at a licensed real estate agency in nearby Jamsil-dong said, "Properties have increased from the usual 10 or so to 15-20, but both sellers and buyers are taking a wait-and-see approach, so no transactions are taking place," and "With many buyers waiting, once we pass this brief 'catching our breath' phase, housing prices will fall further."

APEC Summary... Success in Oral Statement of Concern Over North Korean Nuclear Issue: The 14th Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit held in Hanoi, Vietnam, issued a chairman's oral statement regarding North Korea's nuclear program before closing on the 19th. Leaders from various countries expressed deep concern, dedicating substantial portions of bilateral and multilateral meetings to the North Korean nuclear issue. President Roh Moo-hyun, speaking 19th in the summit's second day of meetings, announced that Korea plans to contribute $2 million to the APEC support fund for capacity building in developing countries in the region from 2007 to 2009. The issuance of a separate oral statement on the North Korean nuclear issue at APEC reflects the fact that leaders from the 21 member countries shared such serious concern about the North Korean nuclear problem. However, leaders reportedly engaged in fierce debate over the format and content of the statement. Ultimately, given that North Korea had expressed its intention to return to six-party talks and meetings were scheduled for next month, the decision was made for a chairman's oral statement containing leaders' urging to achieve substantial results rather than provoke North Korea. The chairman's oral statement is not an official document and has no binding force, taking the form of a recommendation. According to government officials attending APEC, the oral statement expressed clear concern about North Korea's missile launches and nuclear weapons tests while focusing on early resumption of six-party talks and substantial, efficient measures based on last year's September 19 joint statement.

'Fairy' Kim Yuna's First Adult Competition Victory: 'Figure skating fairy' Kim Yuna (16, Gunpo Suri High School) achieved the feat of her first victory on the adult stage at the 2006-07 International Skating Union (ISU) Figure Skating Senior Grand Prix Series 4th competition. Kim Yuna scored the highest 119.32 points among 11 competitors in the women's singles free skating held at the Bercy Indoor Ice Rink in Paris, France on the 19th (Korean time), taking first place. Combined with the 65.22 points (1st place) she received in the short program held the previous day, her total score of 184.54 points beat Japan's Ando Miki (174.44 points) for overall first place. This is the first time a Korean skater has won a gold medal on the ISU senior Grand Prix stage in 100 years of Korean figure skating history. Kim Yuna, who became the first Korean skater to win gold at the World Junior Figure Skating Championships in Slovenia last March, conquered the senior stage in just eight months, raising the possibility of a gold medal at the 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics.

[JoongAng Ilbo] 'New City Housing Sales Possible from 2010, Not 2008': Due to post-completion sales system application, delayed over 2 years from government announcement. While the government decided through the November 15 real estate measures to significantly increase new city housing supply from 2008, it appears that full-scale housing sales will only be possible from 2010. From 2010, the government plans to include household income and real estate assets as scoring factors through subscription system reforms, making it virtually difficult for homeowners or high-income earners to enter new cities in popular areas like Songpa. According to the Ministry of Construction and Transportation on the 20th, with the revision of land development project processing guidelines on the 17th, sales can only be made from next year after business approval and construction progress exceeds 40%. Public land supplied to private companies is also likely to become post-completion sales, as companies applying for post-completion sales receive priority in business selection. A Ministry of Construction and Transportation official said, "According to these regulations, most new cities built in the future will be subject to the post-completion sales system," and "Considering it takes about 1-2 years to reach 40% construction progress, actual sales will be possible about 2 years after business approval." Furthermore, the government plans to strengthen the post-completion sales construction progress standard to 60% from 2009, so sales schedules for new cities like Songpa, Incheon Geomdan, Paju Phase 3, and Pyeongtaek are expected to be further delayed.

[Hankyoreh] Pro-Democracy Figure Tainted by Gift Certificate Corruption: Park Sung-hoon (49), one of the key figures in the 1970s Yonsei University student movement, was arrested by prosecutors on suspicions of adult gaming machine corruption. With Park's arrest, attention is focused on whether allegations that game and gift certificate company officials approached pro-democracy figures for business selection lobbying will be clarified. Park led the October 1977 'Yonsei Democratic Defense Struggle Declaration' incident, considered the largest anti-Yushin university student protest during the Park Chung-hee regime's 'Emergency Measure No. 9' era, which even punished critical remarks about the constitution. This protest, called the 'Muak Valley Battle' in student movement history, began with Yonsei University students demanding abolition of the Yushin system and lifting of emergency measures, then expanded significantly as it spread to nearby Ewha Womans University and Sogang University. About 4,000 students came out of the school gates for the first time since the declaration of Emergency Measure No. 9 in 1975, occupying the Sinchon area of Seoul and engaging in fierce stone-throwing battles with police. Park was sentenced to one year in prison for this incident and is known to have devoted himself to labor movements afterward. The Seoul Central District Prosecutors' Special Investigation Team announced on the 19th that Park is charged with receiving 200 million won [approximately $150,000 USD] from a gift certificate issuing company (aggravated bribery under the Special Act on Punishment of Specific Crimes). According to prosecutors, Park received a request from Kim, CEO of Company H which issues leisure culture gift certificates, in March 2005 to "help get selected as a certified gift certificate issuing company," then told Kim that "contact with Ministry of Culture or Game Industry Development Agency screening committee members had been made," and received money the following month after Company H was selected as a certified gift certificate company.

[Hankook Ilbo] Not One Follows 'Tuition Standards': In a recent special crackdown by the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education, about 28% of hagwons were caught charging excessive tuition fees beyond government-set standards. However, when the Hankook Ilbo planning team randomly selected 50 hagwons in Seoul and metropolitan areas for supplementary education, college entrance exams, essay writing, and language instruction to investigate tuition collection practices from the 18th to 29th of last month, not a single hagwon was found to properly follow government guidelines. This is analyzed to be because while hagwons use sophisticated methods such as false tuition posting, separate credit card payments, and depositing tuition into instructor-named accounts to avoid crackdowns, government oversight remains superficial due to insufficient manpower and inadequate continuous monitoring systems. According to our reporting team's investigation, among all 50 target hagwons, 30 hagwons (60%) charged tuition 100% or more above standards, with 10 of these (20%) exceeding 200%. Additionally, there were 12 hagwons (24%) exceeding by 50-99%, and 8 hagwons (16%) exceeding by 1-49%. This differs significantly from the Seoul Metropolitan Office of Education's special crackdown from July 23 to August 7, which targeted 244 hagwons in Gangnam [an affluent district in Seoul], Yangcheon, and Nowon districts and caught 68 hagwons (27.8% of total) violating tuition standards.

[Kyunghyang Shinmun] Individual Bankruptcy Applications Likely to Exceed 100,000: Due to economic downturn effects, individual bankruptcy applications are expected to exceed 100,000 for the first time this year. According to financial sector sources and the Supreme Court on the 19th, the number of individual bankruptcy applicants from January through September this year was 85,455, 3.6 times the 23,708 in the same period last year and far exceeding last year's total of 38,773. Since April, monthly individual bankruptcy applicants have reached 10,000-11,000 levels, and if this trend continues, total individual bankruptcy applicants this year are expected to exceed 100,000 for the first time, reaching 110,000-120,000. Private research institute officials diagnose that while the number of applicants has increased partly due to relaxed bankruptcy application requirements, the fundamental cause is poor income and employment conditions.

[Kookmin Ilbo] 'The Host' Wins 6 Awards at Korea Film Awards: The film 'The Host' (produced by Chungeoram) proved itself this year's most talked-about film by winning 6 categories including Best Picture and Best Director at the 5th Korea Film Awards. At the ceremony held from 6 PM on the 19th at Universal Art Center in Seoul's Neung-dong, 'The Host' swept 6 categories including Best Picture and Best Director, as well as Best Cinematography, Best Lighting, Best Visual Effects, and Best Sound. The Best Actor award went to Jo In-sung for 'A Dirty Carnival.' The Best Actress award went to Jang Jin-young from 'Love, So Divine,' who appeared as a presenter in place of Jeon Do-yeon, who could not attend the ceremony. Best Supporting Actor and Actress awards went to Lee Beom-su for 'The King and the Clown' and Chu Ja-hyun for 'Between Love and Hate.' The Best New Actor award went to Lee Jun-gi for his passionate performance in 'The King and the Clown.'

[Dong-A Ilbo] 'Floating Stage' Coming to Han River: From next spring, cultural and artistic performances can be enjoyed on a 'floating stage' on the Han River. Seoul Han River Citizen Park Office announced on the 20th, "Starting around April next year, we plan to allow cultural and artistic groups to install floating stages on the Han River using barges (flat-bottomed cargo transport ships) for performances." However, since barges are reserve supplies and their conversion to other uses is prohibited, they cannot be used as permanent stages but only temporarily. The office is considering the Nanji District's 1st Waterside Stage as the primary candidate for floating stage installation. This location already has a 3,000-seat tiered audience area, so performances can begin immediately once a stage is installed.

[Chosun Ilbo] 'Returned POW' No. 1 Jo Chang-ho Dies: At the funeral home for Reserve Lieutenant Jo Chang-ho (76), who died of chronic illness at 0:30 AM on the 19th at Seoul National University Bundang Hospital, his wife Yoon Shin-ja (66) sat in a daze looking at his portrait. "He used to beat his chest saying there are still many Korean War POWs in North Korea suffering from pneumoconiosis and dying after harsh coal mine labor. If the government ignores soldiers in danger, who will fight for the country? He was also heartbroken that he would never see the children he left behind in North Korea." Jo was a 'returned dead man' - the first Korean War POW to escape North Korea and return to South Korea in 1994.

Postscript: The educational backgrounds of 'star' executives at Samsung Electronics, Korea's largest company, show that befitting a global company, one in five graduated from foreign universities, and contrary to expectations, only about 7% are from Seoul National University, Korea's top university. According to Samsung Electronics' quarterly report (as of November 4) submitted on the 20th, among 721 executives excluding outside directors, advisors, consultants, and advisory roles, 138 graduated from foreign universities - overwhelmingly the most - while Seoul National University had only 56. Even combining all three prestigious universities called 'SKY' - Seoul National University, Yonsei University (39), and Korea University (32) - they account for only 17%, less than one-fifth of total executives. Regional differences were striking, with 96 executives from Gyeongsang Province schools including Kyungpook National University (63), Pusan National University (14), and Yeungnam University (12), while each Jeolla Province university had only 1-2 graduates. KAIST and Hanyang University, strong in engineering, accounted for significant portions with 55 and 54 executives respectively, while Sungkyunkwan University, in whose foundation management Samsung Group participates, had 58 - the third most after foreign universities and Kyungpook National University."

However, the Supreme Court continues to harbor suspicious views that prosecutors are deliberately spreading baseless rumors about Chief Justice Lee to the media, creating a subtly evolving conflict. Perhaps conscious of the repercussions his remarks might bring, Chief Justice Lee was cautious with his words when reporters met him on his way to work on the 20th, asking if he believed there were 'forces undermining him,' to which he replied, 'Where are such undermining forces?' and avoided elaborating. When asked if he intended to disclose his legal representation records, given that he had first mentioned and denied tax evasion allegations, he showed an agitated expression and responded 'The reporters are investigating everything...' as if the question wasn't worth answering. From 10 AM that day, prosecutors held a weekly executive meeting chaired by Prosecutor General Jeong to discuss remedial measures regarding media play allegations, the warrant rejection incident, and quasi-appeal issues.

Seoul City's New City Hall Rejected by Cultural Heritage Committee for Third Time
The construction of Seoul City's new city hall has been stymied by 'cultural heritage protection' justifications. With the Cultural Heritage Committee rejecting Seoul City's new city hall construction plan three times, groundbreaking within the year has been scrapped and budget losses from design changes are snowballing. There are widespread criticisms that working-level departments are responding carelessly despite the Cultural Heritage Committee making the same demands three times. The two sides have vastly different perspectives on the new city hall. The city argues that 'the new city hall should become a landmark symbolizing Seoul as an international city,' while the Cultural Heritage Committee maintains its position that it 'should harmonize with the historic site Deoksugung Palace.' A police official explained that '20% of reference book and textbook prices are provided to teachers as bribes.' The National Police Agency's Special Investigation Division on the 20th filed charges without detention against 30 teachers from 7 high schools, including Kwon (47), for bribery and breach of trust, and 3 people including Kang (45), president of a book distributor who gave money to them, for offering bribes. According to police, Kang and others are suspected of lobbying teachers for textbook adoption since 2002, giving 27 million won [approximately $20,000 USD] over 44 occasions. When teachers adopted textbooks with average unit prices of 4,000–5,000 won [approximately $3–4 USD], they provided 1,000–1,500 won [approximately $0.75–1.15 USD] per student who purchased the books as kickbacks. Police explained that corrupt teachers also pocketed 200,000–5 million won [approximately $150–3,800 USD] in kickbacks when reference books and problem sets other than textbooks were used jointly at schools. A police official said, 'At some schools, teachers who received lobbying from different publishers fought over textbook selection and bribe amounts.' A police official said, 'As of early last year, about 1,500 types of textbooks were published, and lobbying by publishers and book distributors to get them adopted as school materials has become routine.'

Chairman Kim Geun-tae 'Considering National Audit of Dongtan Profiteering'
Uri Party Chairman Kim Geun-tae said on the 20th regarding civic groups' allegations that Hwaseong Dongtan New City construction companies made excessive profits of 1 trillion won [approximately $750 million USD] through inflated sale prices, 'While judicial authorities should investigate first, if necessary, we need to consider even a national audit.' At the party's emergency committee meeting that day, Chairman Kim said, 'We will respond with the recognition that real estate speculation is a national disease and an enemy of the Republic of Korea,' adding, 'According to claims by several of our party members and Citizens' Coalition for Economic Justice, there was 1.2 trillion won [approximately $900 million USD] in inflated sale prices during the Hwaseong Dongtan New City construction process, and if this is true, it's an outrageous matter.' He said, 'If Hwaseong City knowingly turned a blind eye and construction companies made unjust excessive profits, we must uncover the truth and correct it,' demanding that 'the government should also mobilize public authority to root out real estate speculation.' Citizens' Coalition for Economic Justice held a press conference on the 17th claiming that Gyeonggi Hwaseong Dongtan New City construction companies made excessive profits of 1.202 trillion won [approximately $900 million USD] by inflating land costs and construction costs.

President Roh Visits Cambodia
President Roh Moo-hyun, on a state visit to Cambodia, said at an overseas Koreans meeting at a Phnom Penh hotel on the 20th, 'In our country, leaders are popular at first, but as time passes, their popularity keeps disappearing.' President Roh said, 'I met with Prime Minister Hun Sen and the National Assembly Speaker and other leaders, and they are all leaders who stood with the people and devoted themselves at risk during times when people were killed and suffered under violent regimes,' adding, 'The leaders of this country are still continuously respected.' This remark is interpreted as expressing regret about some previously respected leaders during Korea's democratization period being disparaged later. It also seems related to President Roh's recent declining public approval ratings. President Roh proudly said, 'We used to live under colonial rule, fight civil war, and live noisily, but when I became president, I found we're supporting about 47 countries,' adding, 'There's no precedent in the world of a formerly colonized country supporting other countries.' President Roh earlier held summit talks with Prime Minister Hun Sen and exchanged opinions on ways to strengthen practical bilateral cooperation in economy and trade, development cooperation, and culture and consular affairs. The Korean government decided to provide a total of 72 million USD [approximately $72 million USD] in grants and loans, including 31 million USD [approximately $31 million USD] for road information network expansion projects and 4 million USD [approximately $4 million USD] to support establishing Cambodia's stock exchange. The two governments signed agreements including a local administrative computerization network construction project implementation agreement, an employment permit workforce dispatch memorandum of understanding, and a diplomatic and official passport visa exemption agreement.

[Hankyoreh] 35 Real Estate Agencies in Eunma Apartment Shopping Complex Alone
The recent real estate turmoil is also seriously affecting Korea's economy, which is suffering from economic recession. Business owners and workers are losing motivation, and ordinary people who borrowed money to buy homes are tightening their belts due to interest payments, prolonging the domestic demand slump. Meanwhile, real estate agencies are rapidly increasing and competition rates for real estate departments are soaring, with money and personnel flocking to real estate-related industries. Experts worry that this distorted fever will lead to a decline in our economy's growth potential. According to Korea Licensed Real Estate Agent Association statistics, while the number of real estate agencies nationwide increased by 8,256 over 5 years from 1997, in the following 5 years (2002-September 2006), a whopping 28,031 increased to reach 77,711. In just one building of the Eunma Shopping Complex next to the Eunma Apartments in Daechi-dong [a Gangnam neighborhood known as the epicenter of Korea's elite hagwon industry], Gangnam-gu [an affluent district in Seoul], a symbol of expensive apartments, 35 real estate agencies are located. As housing prices have continued rising for over 5 years, household housing-related loans and interest burdens keep increasing. Recently, money flowing into the stock market is also decreasing. Dr. Kang Kyung-hoon of the Korea Institute of Finance predicted, 'People and funds flocking only to real estate, which is far from expanding growth potential or creating added value, will adversely affect the economy.'

[Korea Daily] Where Do 'Presidential Candidates' Spending Over 100 Million Won [approximately $75,000 USD] Monthly Get Funding?
The race among leading presidential candidates targeting the 17th presidential election is gaining momentum. How do presidential candidates cover the enormous costs involved? This is a question currently arising in political circles and academia. Among the 6 leading presidential candidates from ruling and opposition parties, 4 people - former Seoul Mayor Lee Myung-bak, former Prime Minister Goh Kun, former Uri Party Chairman Jeong Dong-young, and former Gyeonggi Governor Son Hak-kyu - are 'unemployed' with no fixed income, excluding current lawmakers Kim Geun-tae, Uri Party Chairman, and former Grand National Party leader Park Geun-hye. Even lawmakers' monthly salary is only about 8.72 million won [approximately $6,500 USD]. However, political sources estimate that the costs presidential candidates and their core staff spend monthly amount to at least 70 million to 140 million won [approximately $52,500–105,000 USD]. Most presidential candidates have established camp offices of 30-95 pyeong [approximately 1,200–3,800 square feet] and have 5-15 full-time staff and employees. Including office operating costs and full-time staff activity expenses, monthly camp operating costs alone amount to about 26 million to 50 million won [approximately $19,500–37,500 USD]. Moreover, costs for presidential candidates' overseas visits or regional tours are analyzed to reach 20 million to 30 million won [approximately $15,000–22,500 USD] monthly.

[Kyunghyang Shinmun] Financial Institution Sponsorship Money Used as 'Local Government Head's Pocket Money'
Local governments are using sponsorship money received from treasury operating institutions in exchange for entrusting budgets like pocket money. Jeollabuk-do Province received 50 billion won [approximately $37.5 million USD] in cooperative project costs from Nonghyup [National Agricultural Cooperative Federation], selected as the provincial treasury after agreeing to entrust 1.7 trillion won [approximately $1.3 billion USD] for 2 years in 2004, and has collected 44.7 billion won [approximately $33.5 million USD] so far. However, this money was concentrated on organizations with personal connections to the former governor. Chungcheongnam-do Province's treasury, Nonghyup, paid 10 billion won [approximately $7.5 million USD] in sponsorship money this year alone and handled sales of 150,000 out of 400,000 total advance tickets for the Geumsan Ginseng Expo event. Professor Kim Chang-hwan of Iksan University pointed out, 'Cooperative project funds created with the intention of returning part of the profits from securing provincial treasury to local society are being used like slush funds without budget items,' adding, 'If receiving funds for social return of treasury profits, the amount should be minimized while establishing fund management committees to use them appropriately for purposes like establishing scholarship foundations.'

[Kukmin Ilbo] 101 Local Election Winners Face Election Nullification Sentences
With prosecutors facing the statute of limitations expiry for the 4th May 31 Local Elections just 10 days away on the 20th, 101 winners prosecuted for election law violations have been sentenced to election nullification in first trials, making mass re-elections inevitable. According to the Supreme Court and Supreme Prosecutors' Office, 342 winners have been prosecuted for providing money and entertainment, spreading false information, and pre-election campaigning, with 101 out of 266 who completed first trials (37.8%) receiving election nullification sentences, while 76 are still undergoing first trials. Prosecutors plan to continue investigating election crimes until the 6-month statute of limitations expires on the 30th of this month. A Supreme Court official said, 'Since final judgments for 21 metropolitan and basic local government heads pending in the Supreme Court are expected soon, Supreme Court final judgments will continue around year-end and New Year.'

[Dong-A Ilbo] Professor Lee Pil-sang Named New Korea University President
The Korea University corporation Korea Central Academy Board of Directors (Chairman Hyeon Seung-jong) held a board meeting on the 20th and unanimously appointed Professor Lee Pil-sang (59) of Business Administration as the new president. With Professor Lee, who graduated from Seoul National University's Department of Metallurgical Engineering, being appointed president, Korea University will have a Seoul National University graduate as president for the first time since its founding. President-designate Lee will be the first non-Korea University graduate to serve as president since the 9th president Kim Jun-yeop (Keio University graduate in Japan), who served until 1985. He competed closely with Professor Lee Ki-soo (61) of Law until the end and will assume the 16th presidency starting next month according to the board's decision. Born in 1947 and from Hwaseong, Gyeonggi Province, President-designate Lee has high public recognition due to his activities in civic organizations such as Citizens' Coalition for Economic Justice.

[Chosun Ilbo] Hong Jun-pyo Proposes 'Half-Price Apartment' Bill
Grand National Party lawmaker Hong Jun-pyo submitted the 'Special Measures Act for Promoting Supply of Land-Lease Sale Housing' to the National Assembly on the 20th with signatures from over 40 ruling and opposition lawmakers to substantiate the so-called 'half-price apartment' policy he promoted during the Seoul mayoral candidate primary within the party last April. Lawmaker Hong Jun-pyo explained, 'The special measures act proposed this time legislates a new housing supply method that dramatically lowers apartment sale prices by having construction companies sell only buildings during apartment sales while the state, local governments, and public institutions virtually permanently lease land to homeless ordinary people at cost level.' Lawmaker Hong also proposed the 'Korea Land and Housing Corporation Act' that integrates the Korea National Housing Corporation and Korea Land Corporation into the 'Korea Land and Housing Corporation' so these two institutions can be faithful to their original establishment purpose of 'realizing housing welfare by supplying quality housing and land to ordinary people at low prices' rather than pursuing profit.

[JoongAng Ilbo] 'Websites Dormant Over 3 Months to Be Eliminated'
Tens of thousands of homepages with no visitors for long periods or unchanged content will disappear. The Ministry of Information and Communication is conducting a 'Dormant Homepage Cleanup Campaign' from the 20th to December 8th. During this period, the Ministry will investigate domestic internet cafes, blogs, and homepages, cleaning up sites unused for over 3 months. Ministry Information Protection Policy Team Leader Seo Seok-jin explained, 'This is because there are many cases of hackers exploiting long-abandoned homepages for hacking or spreading malicious codes.' The Ministry conducted a first campaign in June this year, eliminating 53,600 homepages.

An institution conducting qualification exams announced plans to invalidate exams where answers were marked and hold re-examinations, but test-takers are rebelling. The Korea Teacher Training Institute, which administered the exam, distributed test papers with underlines beneath correct answers for all 40 questions to test-takers during the Word Level 1 certification course exam held nationwide on the 18th. When test papers with revealed answers were distributed, test-takers reported this to proctors, but they proceeded saying 'Let's take the exam first and then devise measures.' The exam was taken by 82 out of 95 elementary, middle, and high school teachers who applied after paying 60,000 won [approximately $45 USD] tuition for internet distance training. The private training institution Korea Teacher Training Institute called test-takers the next day on the 19th saying 'We will refund tuition and conduct re-examinations next month.'"
